title: Curriculum Vitae
text: Download Full CV (PDF)

title: Curriculum Vitae
text:
Professional Summary
Final-year PhD candidate at UCL’s Social Research Institute with 4+ years’ experience evaluating social policies using advanced quantitative methods, administrative data, and mixed methods approaches. Published researcher with a track record of translating complex statistical analyses into policy-relevant outputs and integrating qualitative insights, including evidence contributing to current UK parliamentary legislation. Expert in causal inference, quasi-experimental design, and secure data management across ONS and UCL platforms.

title: Curriculum Vitae
text:
Education
PhD Social Science | University College London | 2021 – Present (Expected early 2026)

Thesis: “The Limits of Retrospective Evaluation: Lessons from Multi-Agency Front Door Services for Future Complex Intervention Research in England”
Advanced training: Cambridge Econometrics Summer School (2025) – TWFE, DiD, Machine Learning for Causal Inference
Additional training: CEMMAP Policy Evaluation, Hospital Episode Statistics, ONS Administrative Data

MSc Social Research Methods | University College London | 2019 – 2021 | Distinction

Modules: Advanced Quantitative Methods, Regression Analysis, Impact Evaluation, Systematic Reviews

MSc Public Policy | Universidad de Chile | 2014 – 2016 | Distinction
BSc Economics | Escuela Superior de Economía y Negocios (ESEN), El Salvador | 2008 – 2012

title: Curriculum Vitae
text:
Research Experience
Research Fellow (PT) | UCL Division of Psychiatry and Centre for Longitudinal Studies | November 2025 – Present

ECHILD website data management using RStudio and GitHub

Research Assistant (PT) | UCL Division of Psychiatry and Centre for Longitudinal Studies | October 2025 – Present

Prepared statistical analysis plan to evaluate educational policy on LGBTQ+ young people’s mental health outcomes
Applying quasi-experimental methods for causal inference (Difference-in-Differences, Interrupted Time Series, Two-Way Fixed Effects)
Contributing to creation of the PPIE plan

Research Lead | Thomas Coram Research Unit, UCL | February 2024 – September 2025

Led qualitative implementation and process evaluation of Multi-Agency Safeguarding Hubs (MASH) across England, producing evidence now supporting the Children’s School and Wellbeing Bill in Parliament and Working Together 2025
Analysed nationwide survey data (111/152 Local Authorities) to map service variations and inform strategic case study selection
Co-authored major policy report (Foundations, 2025), influencing national safeguarding policy framework

Research Assistant | ICH Population, Policy & Practice, UCL | August 2022 – February 2023

Led rapid systematic review of child development assessment tools
Co-authored Department of Health and Social Care-commissioned report on 2-2½ year developmental health tool
Published findings in BMJ Open (2024)

Research Assistant | International Inequalities Institute, LSE | September 2019 – September 2021

Conducted quantitative analysis on well-being and job quality using longitudinal surveys from 9+ countries
Co-authored three peer-reviewed publications in high-impact journals

title: Curriculum Vitae
text:
Teaching Experience
Seminar Leader | UCL Social Research Institute | 2022 – Present

Advanced Quantitative Methods (MSc): Teaching multilevel modelling using STATA and R
Introduction to Regression Analysis/Foundations of Data Science (MSc): Linear, logistic, and multinomial regression
R Coding Therapy Sessions (BSc): Led weekly problem-solving sessions supporting 30+ dissertation students

title: Curriculum Vitae
text:
Technical Skills
Statistical Software: STATA (10+ years, teaching level), R/RStudio (4+ years, teaching level), NVivo, QGIS/ArcGIS, SQL, Python
Quantitative Methods: Causal inference, quasi-experimental design, propensity score matching, instrumental variables, Two-Way Fixed Effects, multilevel modelling, panel data analysis, Difference-in-differences, synthetic controls, regression discontinuity
Qualitative Methods: Semi-structured interviews, focus group facilitation, thematic analysis, framework analysis, PPIE
Data Platforms: REDCap, UCL Data Safe Haven, ONS Secure Research Service, web scraping, text mining

title: Research
text: My research focuses on evaluating social policies to improve outcomes for children and young people, with expertise in quasi-experimental methods, administrative data analysis, and mixed methods approaches.

title: Research
text:
Working Papers & Pre-Prints

Multi-agency front door services within children’s social care in England: A scoping review and national survey
Méndez Pineda R, Grant C, Blythe F, Harron K & Woodman J (2025)
This paper presents findings from a scoping review and the first comprehensive national survey of Multi-Agency Safeguarding Hubs (MASH) in England, mapping implementation across 111 of 152 Local Authorities.
Pre-Print



A qualitative study of stakeholder perspectives on adopting a digital tool to measure child development at the 2-2½ year review in England
Lysons JL, Méndez Pineda R, Aquino MRJ, Cann H, Fearon P, Kendall S, et al. (2025)
Pre-Print

title: Research
text:
PhD Research
Thesis: “An Evaluation of Multi-Agency Front Door Services in England”
My doctoral research examines the implementation and effectiveness of Multi-Agency Front Door Services (MAFDs) across England using:

ECHILD: Linked administrative data including National Pupil Database and Hospital Episode Statistics (2008-2022)
National survey: Designed and deployed via REDCap with 73% response rate (111/152 Local Authorities)
Text mining: Web scraped and analysed 3,000+ Ofsted reports (2004-2023) to identify MAFDs implementation dates
Quasi-experimental methods: Difference-in-Differences, Synthetic controls

title: Research
text:
Work in Progress

ECHILD website development and data management

title: Rocío (Ro) Méndez Pineda
text:
I am a final-year PhD candidate at UCL’s Social Research Institute. My research focuses on evaluating social policies using advanced quantitative methods, administrative data, and mixed methods approaches to improve outcomes for children and young people.
My work has contributed to current UK parliamentary legislation, by providing evidence supporting the Children’s School and Wellbeing Bill and Working Together.
